author: muhdraffiq
content: hi guys, does one need to be accepted to the program first to be able to participate in this discord channel?

author: somaditya.
content: No.

author: muhdraffiq
content: oh cool. I thought only the accepted ones are supposed to be here. I would like to contribute in this program. I have gone through the program description and its repo. I am assuming this program is open for anyone to join any protocol or project proposed in the repo. is that correct? and it is open for anyone with different level of technical competency?

author: pipermerriam
content: Understanding the yellow paper... not critical... but you will have to eventually understand how the protocol works.  Understanding the yellow paper is a somewhat difficult way to gain this understanding.  An alternate route to this knowledge could be to read the source code of any of the implementations of the EVM.  The yellow paper is hard to read and in my opinion, not well optimized for easy understanding.

author: muhdraffiq
content: awesome. do you have recommendation links to the source code? I have so far tried reading the yellow page but it is difficult for me to understand. I have seen a video on of dev talks about EVM and stuff, that had helped a little bit in the yellow paper

author: cybersyn3988
content: Hi! As someone who is more experienced with Python, I'd like to learn about the protocol by understanding py-evm and Trinity, but I don't really know how to start, I feel a bit overwhelmed when looking at their repos. Do you have any recommendation on how to understand their respective documentations?

author: ralexstokes
content: https://github.com/ethereum/py-evm/tree/master/eth/vm this module has the virtual machine, can be a good place to start

author: ralexstokes
content: then the next layer out is understanding how a transaction on-chain maps to an evm execution

author: ralexstokes
content: and that is most of the state transition

author: ralexstokes
content: you can do all of this w/o having to even really think about networking, which is kind of its own separate layer

author: voith
content:
Hi Everyone,
I am Voith. I have previously contributed to python's Ethereum tooling. I have been active in this space since early 2018. In 2020, I got busy with my day job and I could no longer contribute. I've recently quit my day job and I have decided to take a deep dive in understanding the Ethereum protocol. I recently got to know about this programme from Piper and thought that this exactly what I was planning to do. 
My primary interest is in understanding the EVM. Although, I'm no stranger to the protocol, I am by no means an expert. I aim to have expert level knowledge about each and every Opcode.
I'll be starting my research again from 1st June(Currently serving my notice period).
<@!543900561460822016>  As per Pipers suggestion in <#688075293562503241> about getting eth1 spec'd like `eth2-specs` I wanted to let you know that I'm very much interested in this and I will get in touch with you after 1st June.

author: dahwool
content:
Hello!
I am Darryl, I am a student in my final year of Mathematics at the University of Calgary. I got into the space in mid-2017, and have been growing my foundations in cryptography, and Go blockchain development since. I have some experience with project management, as well as programming and smart contracts. Some of my interests for contributing to Post-Quantum Cryptography models, as well as a mathematical/development implementation of DAOs with triple entry bookkeeping. 

I am eager to learn more about both ethereum development, and more about the apprenticeship program. I hope to learn more from a research perspective, as well how to contribute to implementations of Ethereum protocols, and further development.
